messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 57 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Network Calculus Characterization of Congestion Control for Time-Varying Traffic

Paper Abstract: Abstract Models for the dynamics of congestion control generally involve systems of coupled differential equations. Universally, these models assume that traffic sources saturate the maximum transmissions allowed by the congestion control method. This is not suitable for studying congestion control of intermittent but bursty traffic sources. In this paper, we present a characterization of congestion control for arbitrary time-varying traffic that applies to rate-based as well as window-based congestion control. We leverage the capability of network calculus to precisely describe the input-output relationship at network elements for arbitrary source traffic. We show that our characterization can closely track the dynamics of even complex congestion control algorithms.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 57 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 57"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "High-resolution measurement of data center microbursts",
        "Bullet trains: a study of NIC burst behavior at microsecond timescales",
        "Catching the microburst culprits with Snappy",
        "Observing and mitigating micro-burst traffic in data center networks",
        "Congestion control for large-scale RDMA deployments",
        "Data center TCP (DCTCP): TCP congestion control for data centers",
        "HPCC: high precision congestion control",
        "TIMELY: RTT-based congestion control for the datacenter",
        "Swift: delay is simple and effective for congestion control in the datacenter",
        "Datacenter congestion control",
        "Hierarchical congestion control (HCC): fairness and fast convergence for data centers",
        "Improving ECN marking scheme with micro-burst traffic in data center networks",
        "ACC: automatic ECN tuning for high-speed datacenter networks",
        "InfiniBand Architecture Specification, Volume 1, Release 1.2.1",
        "InfiniBand Architecture Specification Release 1.2.1 Annex A17: RoCEv2",
        "AC/DC TCP: virtual congestion control enforcement for datacenter networks",
        "Fluid models and solutions for large-scale IP networks",
        "Towards stability analysis of data transport mechanisms: a fluid model and its applications",
        "The Mathematics of Internet Congestion Control",
        "Internet congestion control",
        "How good are deterministic fluid models of internet congestion control?",
        "Analysis of DCTCP: stability, convergence, and fairness",
        "Model-based insights on the performance, fairness, and stability of BBR",
        "Deep residual learning for image recognition",
        "Network calculus: a theory of deterministic queueing systems for internet",
        "Performance guarantees in communication networks",
        "Deterministic network calculus: from theory to practical implementation",
        "Toward formally verifying congestion control behavior",
        "TCP Vegas: end to end congestion avoidance on a global internet",
        "Performance bounds for flow control protocols",
        "Duality of the max-plus and min-plus network calculus",
        "Extending the network calculus algorithmic toolbox for ultimately pseudo-periodic functions: pseudo-inverse and composition",
        "Simulation-based comparisons of Tahoe, Reno and SACK TCP",
        "The addition of explicit congestion notification (ecn) to IP",
        "Random early detection gateways for congestion avoidance",
        "IEEE standard for local and metropolitan area networks–media access control (MAC) bridges and virtual bridged local area networks–Amendment 17: Priority-based Flow Control",
        "Analysis of the increase and decrease algorithms for congestion avoidance in computer networks",
        "Congestion avoidance and control",
        "CUBIC: a new TCP-friendly high-speed TCP variant",
        "The ns-3 Network Simulator",
        "Modeling the throughput of TCP Vegas",
        "How to configure DCQCN values for ConnectX-4",
        "Cisco Data Center Networking Blueprint for AI/ML Applications",
        "Data Center Quantized Congestion Notification (DCQCN)",
        "CloudEngine 16800, 12800, 9800, 8800, 7800, 6800, and 5800 Series Switches Typical Configuration Examples: Configuring an Intelligent Lossless Network",
        "IEEE standard for local and metropolitan area networks–virtual bridged local area network–Amendment 13: Congestion Notification",
        "NS-3 simulator for RDMA",
        "Rate control for communication networks: shadow prices, proportional fairness and stability",
        "Optimization flow control. I. basic algorithm and convergence",
        "A duality model of TCP and queue management algorithms",
        "Understanding TCP Vegas: a duality model",
        "End-to-end congestion control schemes: utility functions, random losses and ECN marks",
        "Fluid-based analysis of a network of AQM routers supporting TCP flows with an application to RED",
        "A control theoretic analysis of RED",
        "Analysis and design of controllers for AQM routers supporting TCP flows",
        "TCP is max-plus linear and what it tells us on its throughput",
        "Network calculus based simulation for TCP congestion control: theorems, implementation and evaluation"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 57 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Network Calculus Characterization of Congestion Control for Time-Varying Traffic, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
